ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: The professor teaches critical skills, and is clearly an expert, but its a bit strange that he himself is a little awkward, despite teaching a communicator course. Don't enroll for the prof, enroll for the content.
Every FES student should take this class; it's incredibly valuable for job interviews and I wish I took the class in my first year.
NA

Question 12The presentation skills provided in this class were very effective when I prepared presentations for other classes. My friends said they found my presentation to be "professional" with images that had sources cited in them.

The personal attention given by coaches in small groups and the broader advice during class were both very useful for improving communication skills. It was unfortunate that some of the classes were cancelled due to weather events, and I wish there had been an opportunity to make these up.

Vance is a good teacher who encourages participation and tries to give us applicable assignments. However, it was not that different from a more extended TSC, and I felt like the continuity got broken up a little by weather-related changes in the class.
William Vance is great!
The instructor was very effective, however I had trouble taking on his rigid format.
This course was useful if you have not had any professional communications experience. Otherwise, its pretty basic.
Communication with the masses is incredibly important to success in my professional field.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: skills learned, well designed projects
Practice!!!

The introduction to simple but effective ways of improving communication at the professional level. Thegroup exercises were an excellent dynamic to foster learning, feedback between peers, and feedback from a professional instructor.
William and Kristin (TA) taught very valuable topics in communications and provided great feedback!
Learning tips and tricks for presentations and powerpoints - these are most relevant to what we do.
The breakout sessions.
Forcing you to actually practice giving a speech, a power point presentation, etc.
Having the opportunity to see myself on film really highlighted things that I need to work on in my presentation style and presence. I learned the most from the first three weeks of the course.
The readings given prior to class were very helpful.
Personal attention and feedback for each student

Super-practical, assignments involved actually doing these things, and were generally useful and fun. It's a good course to give you an overview of professionalism, and to give you some awareness of how you come off as a presenter. These are super-important skills and it's great to actually have a class in it.
Practice time to implement some of the practical tips learned in class.
extremely helpful, the handout and tips were simple but made an enormous difference
Homework assignments were helpful to repeat and practice the material
Very clear explanations of useful, practical material.
The workshop session with the coaches.

I thought the most useful aspects of the class were the speech, and the powerpoint sessions. I liked working with the coaches and the direct feedback they gave. Learning about the communication coaches.

The weekly exercises are very helpful, and provide an excellent opportunity to practice communication skills. In particular, the opportunity to watch video of yourself giving a speech or presentation, and to access feedback from students and TAs, was invaluable, and an opportunity that most of us don't get otherwise in our careers.
Having taped presentations and feedback was valuable.
Coverage of multiple aspects of communication.
The course was very well organized and presented a lot of great tips.

My favorite parts were the in-class exercises where we directly practiced speaking, presenting, and negotiating in front of our peers. The practice was helpful in and of itself, but the timing was extra useful because it gave us the chance to try out the skills Dr. Vance emphasized in the lectures while they were fresh in our minds. I also appreciate that we were allowed to use old presentations and speeches for the in-class exercises rather than creating new content. Since I was already familiar and comfortable with the material, I was able to concentrate more fully on my speaking and delivery.
I liked the presentation portion.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: The lecture itself could be move faster.
Follow-up sessions in spaces and mechanics similar to the ones pertaining to the course itself.
I honestly which it was a longer class for more credits
Time management and the wide variety of skill in the coaches.
Cut the lecture portion significantly. Focus on skill development and practice.

It would be nice to get more thorough feedback immediately after doing your presentation / powerpoint, rather than at the end of the semester. I'd also focus even more on practicing public speaking-- and maybe leave out the writing lecture.
Some of the lessons, particularly towards the end of the semester, were really rudimentary and felt a little bit repetitive. I would focus this class more on presentation skills.
It will be good to spend more time in practicing different skills. Limited time was the main aspect of this course that needs the most improvement.

I would like to have talked more about Environmental Communication specifically, not just professionalism, and how to communicate concepts that are difficult or complicated to a larger audience. In addition, while the lectures are not too long, I do sometimes feel like that time could have been better spent actually applying the concept--writing a facebook post together, etc.
None â for what it is, it works pretty perfectly. It's a little rushed, though -- maybe it could work as a full semester?
The teaching style - it was a "one size fits it all" approach. In real life, inter-personal communication is rarely so.
I wish we received more feedback at the end of the course.

We were not provided with the course lecture materials, even after asking for them repeatedly. we got a hard copy handout of some of the PPT slides at the beginning of each class, which was unecessary as most of us would have preferred to access this digitally. However, this sheet was a summary of the key points only, and we never got access to the entire slide deck from each class. This is something I was expecting that we would get, and we were told we should get, so I did not try to take exhaustive notes each class. Now that the course is over, I would like to reference all the material we were given and re-read through it, however I cannot, as we did not get access to it.

Faster pace and options for more advanced students. Would be nice to have some gender-specific training, as often times women face many more challenges and criticism as communicators. Also, more focus on international communication or communication with different (non corporate, american audiences) would be beneficial.
More time to really improve on skills. In one class we'd be handed some tools and put something together to practice them. Then we'd get feedback and never touch them again.

See question 20.It's inconvenient that no slides were shared with the computers, and information was shared with the class in the form of handouts rather than soft copy. That will make it difficult for our generation to organize and refer back to this information in the future.
No specific areas spring to mind; overall a very solid course.
The course is taught too late at night. It's hard to feel motivated at 9pm.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Very good.
See comment for question 15.
Yes, lectures were good and break out sessions were good.
The professor was very responsive to the needs of the students.

The discussion sections were a place to actually do the work of the course, receive some feedback, and interact in a small group. Although Vance's lectures are an institution in themselves, the discussions seemed more important.
Discussed concepts in lecture, then tried them out in group discussions. Effective structure.
I like the lecture + workshop (small group) combo.
The breakout sessions were super helpful as were the lectures.
n/a

Pretty good in general. Kristen and Michelle were much too serious and unpersonable. It made me and I believe others uncomfortable, which was a big distraction when we were trying to focus on doing the presentations and exercises.
NA

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: everyone's gotta learn how to present and present themselves and speak with authority.
It provides tools to enhance or develop communication skills with a structured and conscious approach.
It is completely relevant to my overall program and was a great class!
Helpful in communicating my research better.
I think good communications skills fit into every program of study.
It was very helpful for practicing my presentation skills.

Effective communication skills is very important for environmental management careers as we have to communicate with diverse groups in our careers. Learning to effectively carry out conversations is very important for good team work and success of a project

I think every student should take this course, as communication skills are very important in all fields. The Environmental field especially requires clear and advanced communication skills to convey complex messages to a broad audience.
This would probably be especially helpful right before going out into the real world of jobs or even internships. It's a good reminder of what you should do and how you should behave.
I intend to be an environmental advocate and writer, and I think this class absolutely made me a more effective communicator.
Communication is a very important aspect of our career as environmentalists.
I think this course is very helpful and I am very glad I took it.
Communication skills are invaluable for everyone, regardless of what field they will enter.
These sessions were good, but often felt cut short or too late. Might be nice to have some weekend courses offered or something earlier in the day to maintain energy levels.
Very important. Everyone should have to take this but I think it should be a full semester.
Professional skill

I am planning on going into policy and government after I finish school, so good communication skills will be critical. In the short term, I'll need those skills for presenting my thesis research at academic conferences. Plus good communication skills are just helpful for life in general.
It was helpful to review communication tactics but it focuses more on networking/professional use rather than being an effective environmentalist.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: Public speaking is beautiful and I like being exposed to it.
I think communication skills are essential for professional excellence and performance.
Recommended.
I thought it would be a good opportunity to work on communication skill development.
To improve my comfort in public speaking and presentations.
To practice my presentation skills
I have heard good things about this class from other students. Besides, I wanted to improve my communication skills.
To learn more about different types of communication and strategies for improving each.
I wanted to learn to be a better communicator, specifically in the environmental realm.
Felt that my public speaking skills needed improvement.
To improve my communication skills and gain confidence.
Communication skills are invaluable for everyone, regardless of what field they will enter.
Improve communication skills
To improve my communication skills.

I did competitive public speaking as a kid, and I wanted to see how the norms and habits I developed through that compared to what would be taught in a class for adult professionals. I also wanted some additional public speaking practice in general. Finally, I wanted to learn more about written professional communication norms, because I hadn't had a formal course in that before.
I thought it would be useful for my communication skills.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: yes
Yes.
Yes
Fairly well.
No. There was a pretty limited amount of time to work on skill development. Again, too much lecture time.
Yes- wish it had been longer with more one on one interaction.
Somewhat
Yes but again due to limited time, we did not get to practice our skills a lot.
Yes
I gained some knowledge about professional skills, but didn't learn much about actually doing environmental work. It was only mildly enviromentally-flavored.
yes!
yes
Yes, absolutely!
Somewhat - depending on what aspect. I loved the negotiation class, but for presentation classes I hoped for more techniques on how to structure contents, not so much on the style of delivery.
yes
Most certainly
No - below expectations. This was a very beginner-level course.
Yes but I wish there had been more time.

This course should not be called 'environmental communicator,' it should be called 'communicator.' I was disappointed that communication skills specific to the needs of an environmental manager weren't taught.Environmentalists need special skills to communicate their agenda (the environment) with people who may not share that agenda (businesses, govt, etc). Environmentalists need strategies to communicate with the public about the environment. There are a large number of other situations in which environmentalists may need specialized communication skills. Specialized skills don't have to make up 100% of the course content, but at least 25-30% of the time. The content presented is good but it needs to be more targeted. Otherwise, the name of the course should be changed.
Yes; overall a very helpful course.
Nothing I learned felt new.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: many advantages. get to see different speaking styles, different deliveries, how people's strengths and weaknesses manifest themselves.
Feedback between peers. It creates safe spaces to try the material learned in class.
Group work is great in this setting, critical to developing communication skills for various settings. Peer feedback is helpful as well.
Better understanding of the homework problems
Provided each other encouragement, tested out ideas, saw what and what not to do, and it was fun!
Group evaluations were helpful, but not always taken seriously.
It was great to work with peers and we got a lot out of working together.

It was helpful to be able to present to and critique each other during the in-class exercises, because peers often pointed out possible improvements in my style and delivery that I had been unaware of. By the same token, I was able to improve my speaking by watching other people and observing how certain styles, gestures, and patterns of speech look from the audience's point of view.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: go for it.
Be conscious in practicing the concepts and tools learned in class in order to incorporate them into your day to day communications.
Take it. It is invaluable to your transition into the real world post-FES
Check out the readings.

Lobby the professor to alter the course to concentrate on skill development and practice. Have a 10 minute lecture about what you are going to practice that week and then rely on your coaches to deliver the main message and help the students build skills.
It is what you make of it-- put some effort into practicing / rehearsing you'll get much more for your money.

The professor and the communication coaches are very helpful in developing the students' communication styles and in delivering contents effectively. This course should be taken by anyone for whom communication both in speaking and writing will be a major part of the career.

It may be a good idea to have a presentation / speech in mind to practice as part of the course. Rather than giving a presentation that has already been presented, I was able to practice an upcoming presentation and get feedback on it in order to better prepare. I think this was extremely helpful and relevant for my spring 2013 activities.
Take it as an extended TSC, maybe towards the end of your career here.
Take it!
I didn't end up taking this course.
Take it--also what you put in is what you get out of it. If you don't have time to take it then at least meed with the communication coaches while at FES.

I would definitely recommend taking this class. Communication skills are essential for every career, and this class will give you an opportunity to hone your communication skills and better represent yourself in your career.
This is a good beginners communications class, but if you are looking for something more rigorous see the communications coaches 1 on 1.
Do the prep work and readings beforehand to be prepared for class. There's so little time you'll want to make the most of it.
Review the things to be covered before taking the course and make sure it matches what you want.
Take it; it's not a lot of extra work and you'll gain some valuable skills.
If you don't have experience with communications, I recommend taking it. It's not a "must take course" though.
